title: 108_s1451
content: The Act titled "Runaway, Homeless, and Missing Children Protection Act" is an amendment to the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act, specifically amending Section 302 regarding findings. The Congress finds that youth who are homeless or run away from home without parental permission are at risk of serious health and behavioral problems. They urgently need temporary shelter and services, including linguistically appropriate care. The Federal Government has a responsibility to address this interstate issue. The Federal Government must develop a national reporting system to address the needs of runaway youth, homeless youth, and street youth. These youth require opportunities for education, job skills training, and employment to successfully transition to adulthood. To address the needs of runaway, homeless, and street youth, a national reporting system is needed. These youth require education, job skills training, and employment opportunities for a successful transition to adulthood. Improved coordination between Federal programs serving this population is crucial for a long-term strategy. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to change the heading to "Basic Center" and include testing for sexually transmitted diseases at the request of youth. An obsolete provision related to certain allotments is repealed. SEC. 104 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act repeals an obsolete provision related to certain allotments. SEC. 105 amends eligibility provisions by replacing "juveniles" with "youth." SEC. 106 recognizes state laws regarding capacity limitations on eligible runaway and homeless youth centers. SEC. 106 amends Section 312(b)(2)(A) of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to recognize state laws on capacity limitations for youth centers. The Runaway and Homeless Youth Act is amended to include maternity group homes and parenting skills in eligibility criteria. A maternity group home is defined as a transitional living arrangement for pregnant or parenting youth to learn parenting skills and promote long-term economic stability. Pregnant or parenting youth in maternity group homes are required to learn parenting skills, family budgeting, and health and nutrition to promote long-term economic independence and ensure the well-being of their children. Limited extension of 540-day shelter eligibility period for youth under 18 years old in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act program. Youth can remain in the program until their 18th birthday or 180 days after the 540-day period ends. SEC. 109 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to involve McKinney-Vento school district liaisons in providing educational services to runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 110 establishes a coordination agreement for Part B of the plan. SEC. 110 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to coordinate services with McKinney-Vento school district liaisons for educational services for runaway and homeless youth. SEC. 111 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to develop a plan for proper referral of homeless youth to various services. SEC. 112 focuses on coordinating programs. SEC. 112 amends the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act to ensure coordination of programs and services for homeless youth by consulting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development. SEC. 113 clarifies grant authority, and SEC. 114 makes a technical amendment relating to demonstration projects. SEC. 115 repeals an obsolete provision in the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act by striking section 345. SEC. 116 amends the age limit for homeless youth seeking shelter in a center under part A. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations for the Act. SEC. 117 authorizes appropriations of $105,000,000 for fiscal year 2004 and necessary sums for fiscal years 2005-2008 for the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. SEC. 118 requires a report on strategies to end youth homelessness within 2 years. SEC. 119 calls for a study on housing services and strategies. SEC. 119 requires a study on housing services and strategies for youth exiting programs funded under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act. It aims to report on long-term housing outcomes, available services, placement strategies, and models to prevent future homelessness. SEC. 120 of the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act prohibits the use of funds for distributing sterile needles for illegal drug injection. Recipients must account for funds separately if carrying out such programs. The Congress recognizes the grave danger faced by abducted children, the risks of physical harm and sexual exploitation for missing children, the lack of resources for search efforts by parents and law enforcement, the need for cooperation between local, State, and Federal law enforcement, and the role of the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children as a national resource center. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children serves as a national resource center and works in partnership with various law enforcement agencies to find missing children and prevent child victimization through a national and worldwide network. The National Center for Missing and Exploited Children collaborates with various law enforcement agencies globally, including Scotland Yard, Royal Canadian Mounted Police, and INTERPOL, to share information and images of missing children instantly. SEC. 202. Authorization of appropriations amended to extend funding for the National Center for Missing and Exploited Children until 2008. This is part of the reauthorization of programs under the Runaway and Homeless Youth Act and the Missing Children's Assistance Act.
